elements.content: High-pressure single-crystal X-ray structural analyses of isostructural MFM-133­(M) (M = Zr, Hf) of flu topology and incorporating the tetracarboxylate ligand TCHB4– [H4TCHB = 3,3′,5,5′-tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl)-2,2′,4,4′,6,6′-hexamethyl-1,1′-biphenyl] and {M6(μ3-OH)8(OH)8(COO)8} clusters confirm negative linear compressibility (NLC) behavior along the c axis. This occurs via a three-dimensional wine-rack NLC mechanism leading to distortion of the octahedral cage toward a more elongated polyhedron under static compression. Despite the isomorphous nature of these two structures, MFM-133­(Hf) shows a higher degree of NLC than the Zr­(IV) analogue. Thus, for the first time, we demonstrate here that the NLC property can be effectively tuned in a framework material by simply varying the inorganic component of the frameworks without changing the network topology and structure.
elements.clean_text: High-pressure single-crystal X-ray structural analyses of isostructural MFM-133(M) (M = Zr, Hf) of flu topology and incorporating the tetracarboxylate ligand TCHB4- [H4TCHB = 3,3',5,5'-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)-2,2',4,4',6,6'-hexamethyl-1,1'-biphenyl] and {M6(μ3-OH)8(OH)8(COO)8} clusters confirm negative linear compressibility (NLC) behavior along the c axis. This occurs via a three-dimensional wine-rack NLC mechanism leading to distortion of the octahedral cage toward a more elongated polyhedron under static compression. Despite the isomorphous nature of these two structures, MFM-133(Hf) shows a higher degree of NLC than the Zr(IV) analogue. Thus, for the first time, we demonstrate here that the NLC property can be effectively tuned in a framework material by simply varying the inorganic component of the frameworks without changing the network topology and structure.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of porous materials constructed from inorganic ions/clusters bridged by organic linkers. Due to their high crystallinity the structures of these materials can often be accurately monitored by crystallographic methods as a function of various external stimuli such as temperature and pressure. Some MOFs undergo processes such as pressure-induced phase transitions and amorphization when exposed to high pressures. The mechanisms for these pressure-induced structural behaviors need to be fully understood before such materials can be considered for practical applications. Although most materials contract in all dimensions under hydrostatic compression, others contract in one direction but expand in one or more directions, a rare phenomenon known as negative linear compressibility (NLC). Only a limited number of materials have been reported to exhibit NLC, the majority of which are inorganic species such as LaNbO4 and elemental Se. A few molecular frameworks including methanol monohydrate and metallocyanides such as Ag3[Co­(CN)6] and KMn­[Ag­(CN)2]3 exhibit NLC properties, but this is extremely rare for MOFs. Materials with NLC properties can find widespread use in high-pressure environments such as deep-sea optical telecommunications devices and piezoresponsive devices (i.e., highly sensitive pressure sensors, smart body armor, and shock-absorbing materials).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of porous materials constructed from inorganic ions/clusters bridged by organic linkers. Due to their high crystallinity the structures of these materials can often be accurately monitored by crystallographic methods as a function of various external stimuli such as temperature and pressure. Some MOFs undergo processes such as pressure-induced phase transitions and amorphization when exposed to high pressures. The mechanisms for these pressure-induced structural behaviors need to be fully understood before such materials can be considered for practical applications. Although most materials contract in all dimensions under hydrostatic compression, others contract in one direction but expand in one or more directions, a rare phenomenon known as negative linear compressibility (NLC). Only a limited number of materials have been reported to exhibit NLC, the majority of which are inorganic species such as LaNbO4  and elemental Se. A few molecular frameworks including methanol monohydrate and metallocyanides such as Ag3[Co(CN)6] and KMn[Ag(CN)2]3  exhibit NLC properties, but this is extremely rare for MOFs. Materials with NLC properties can find widespread use in high-pressure environments such as deep-sea optical telecommunications devices and piezoresponsive devices (i.e., highly sensitive pressure sensors, smart body armor, and shock-absorbing materials).

elements.content: MOF-5 and ZIF-8 have been studied using in situ single-crystal diffraction techniques under hydrostatic pressure. Although these materials show structural changes associated with the penetration of guest molecules of the pressure-transmitting medium into the pores under high pressure, they do not show NLC behavior. Frameworks displaying NLC are generally associated with specific network topologies featuring “wine-rack” or honeycomb-like structural motifs. One well-known example is the MIL-53 family, which exhibits an extremely high degree of NLC, with a compressibility K NLC = −28 TPa–1 over 0–3 GPa. Recently, a β-quartz-like framework [InH­(BDC)2] (H2BDC = benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid) has been reported to exhibit an extreme NLC (−62.4 TPa–1) involving a framework-hinging mechanism. The NLC behavior of both of the above examples correlates with the structural flexibility originating from the system of rigid elements connected by hinges. The organic linkers provide another source of flexibility: frameworks employing large organic struts tend to show some degree of flexibility, but frameworks with both rigid linkers and rigid inorganic clusters should intuitively be rigid in the absence of framework hinging.
elements.clean_text: MOF-5 and ZIF-8 have been studied using in situ single-crystal diffraction techniques under hydrostatic pressure. Although these materials show structural changes associated with the penetration of guest molecules of the pressure-transmitting medium into the pores under high pressure, they do not show NLC behavior. Frameworks displaying NLC are generally associated with specific network topologies featuring "wine-rack" or honeycomb-like structural motifs. One well-known example is the MIL-53 family, which exhibits an extremely high degree of NLC, with a compressibility K NLC = -28 TPa-1 over 0-3 GPa. Recently, a β-quartz-like framework [InH(BDC)2] (H2BDC = benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid) has been reported to exhibit an extreme NLC (-62.4 TPa-1) involving a framework-hinging mechanism. The NLC behavior of both of the above examples correlates with the structural flexibility originating from the system of rigid elements connected by hinges. The organic linkers provide another source of flexibility: frameworks employing large organic struts tend to show some degree of flexibility, but frameworks with both rigid linkers and rigid inorganic clusters should intuitively be rigid in the absence of framework hinging.

elements.content: Herein, we show that two rigid frameworks MFM-133­(M) (M = Zr, Hf) constructed from a rigid tetracarboxylate linker () and {M6(μ3-OH)8(OH)8(COO)8} clusters exhibit unusual NLC behavior, featuring the first examples of porous Zr­(IV)- and Hf­(IV)-based MOFs displaying NLC. Despite the isomorphous nature of these two structures, MFM-133­(Hf) shows a higher degree of NLC than the Zr­(IV) analogue. By analyzing the high-pressure crystallographic data, we reveal the mechanisms behind the different NLC behaviors of these two frameworks, and thus, for the first time, we demonstrate an example of using crystal engineering methods to tune the NLC properties of frameworks materials without altering the underlying topology and structure.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we show that two rigid frameworks MFM-133(M) (M = Zr, Hf) constructed from a rigid tetracarboxylate linker () and {M6(μ3-OH)8(OH)8(COO)8} clusters exhibit unusual NLC behavior, featuring the first examples of porous Zr(IV)- and Hf(IV)-based MOFs displaying NLC. Despite the isomorphous nature of these two structures, MFM-133(Hf) shows a higher degree of NLC than the Zr(IV) analogue. By analyzing the high-pressure crystallographic data, we reveal the mechanisms behind the different NLC behaviors of these two frameworks, and thus, for the first time, we  demonstrate an example of using crystal engineering methods to tune the NLC properties of frameworks materials without altering the underlying topology and structure.

elements.content: Single-crystal structure of MFM-133­(Zr) at ambient pressure and 120 K. Views of (a) the octahedral {Zr6(μ3-OH)8(OH)8(COO)8} cluster and H4TCHB; (b) the conformation of TCHB4– units in the framework showing the twisted geometry of the two central mesitylene rings; (c) the octahedral cage constructed from eight TCHB4– units and six {Zr6} clusters; (d) the (4,8)-connected flu-type topology of MFM-133­(Zr). Color scheme: Zr, green; O, red; C, black.
elements.clean_text: 1  Single-crystal structure of MFM-133(Zr) at ambient pressure and 120 K. Views of (a) the octahedral {Zr6(μ3-OH)8(OH)8(COO)8} cluster and H4TCHB; (b) the conformation of TCHB4- units in the framework showing the twisted geometry of the two central mesitylene rings; (c) the octahedral cage constructed from eight TCHB4- units and six {Zr6} clusters; (d) the (4,8)-connected flu-type topology of MFM-133(Zr). Color scheme: Zr, green; O, red; C, black.

elements.content: Solvothermal reaction of H4TCHB [3,3′,5,5′-tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl)-2,2′,4,4′,6,6′-hexamethyl-1,1′-biphenyl] with ZrCl4 or HfCl4 in DEF (N,N-diethylformamide) at 120 °C in the presence of benzoic acid as modulator afforded single crystals of MFM-133­(Zr) and MFM-133­(Hf), respectively. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction revealed that these two materials are isomorphous, crystallizing in the tetragonal space group P4/mnc. MFM-133­(Zr) contains the 8-connected octahedral {Zr6(μ3-OH)8(OH)8(COO)8} cluster (), which is observed in other Zr-based frameworks. The methyl groups in the central part of TCHB4– enforce a twist of almost 90° between the two central mesitylene rings, resulting in a tetrahedral arrangement of the carboxylate groups of the linker. Each linker is thereby connected to four {Zr6} clusters in a tetrahedral fashion, and the whole framework forms a neutral (4,8)-connected network with fluorite (flu) topology. An axially elongated octahedral cage, with a cavity of diameter 10.4 × 10.4 × 25.9 Å, is constructed from eight TCHB4– units residing on the faces of the polyhedron and six {Zr6} clusters on the vertices. The solvent-accessible void volume for MFM-133­(Zr) was calculated to be 71% using PLATON SOLV, indicating its significantly porous structure. Due to the similar sizes of {Hf6} and {Zr6} clusters, MFM-133­(Hf) shows very similar structural features to MFM-133­(Zr) including the same degree of porosity.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Solvothermal reaction of H4TCHB [3,3',5,5'-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)-2,2',4,4',6,6'-hexamethyl-1,1'-biphenyl] with ZrCl4 or HfCl4 in DEF (N,N-diethylformamide) at 120 °C in the presence of benzoic acid as modulator afforded single crystals of MFM-133(Zr) and MFM-133(Hf), respectively. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction revealed that these two materials are isomorphous, crystallizing in the tetragonal space group P4/mnc. MFM-133(Zr) contains the 8-connected octahedral {Zr6(μ3-OH)8(OH)8(COO)8} cluster (), which is observed in other Zr-based frameworks. The methyl groups in the central part of TCHB4- enforce a twist of almost 90° between the two central mesitylene rings, resulting in a tetrahedral arrangement of the carboxylate groups of the linker. Each linker is thereby connected to four {Zr6} clusters in a tetrahedral fashion, and the whole framework forms a neutral (4,8)-connected network with fluorite (flu) topology. An axially elongated octahedral cage, with a cavity of diameter 10.4 × 10.4 × 25.9 Å, is constructed from eight TCHB4- units residing on the faces of the polyhedron and six {Zr6} clusters on the vertices. The solvent-accessible void volume for MFM-133(Zr) was calculated to be 71% using PLATON SOLV, indicating its significantly porous structure. Due to the similar sizes of {Hf6} and {Zr6} clusters, MFM-133(Hf) shows very similar structural features to MFM-133(Zr) including the same degree of porosity.

elements.content: High-pressure single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments were performed using a diamond anvil cell (DAC) (see ). Before loading a crystal into the DAC, residual DEF solvent from the synthesis was fully exchanged with 4:1 MeOH/EtOH, which was used as the pressure-transmitting medium. For MFM-133­(Zr), diffraction data were collected at 293 K on one single crystal at pressures ranging from ambient to 4.41 GPa. The variation of lattice parameter values as a function of pressure is shown in . It is immediately apparent that upon compression the equivalent a and b axes contract in length, but the c axis expands. Over the pressure range studied, lattice parameter a and the unit cell volume decrease by 0.628(5) Å (3.2%) and 521(6) Å3 (4.2%), respectively, while lattice parameter c increases by 0.732(8) Å (2.2%). The data were fitted using an empirical equation l = l 0 + λ­(p – p c) v , giving the linear compressibilities along a (or b) and c as 5.9 and −5.1 TPa–1, respectively, over the pressure range 0–4.4 GPa. The value of NLC of −5.1 TPa–1 is higher than for other molecular frameworks such as [NH4]­[Zn­(HCOO)3] (K NLC = −1.8 TPa–1) and ZAG-4 (K NLC = −2.6 TPa–1) but lower than metallocyanide frameworks Ag3[Co­(CN)6]-I (K NLC = −76 TPa–1) and KMn­[Ag­(CN)2]3 (K NLC = −12 TPa–1), indicating moderately strong NLC behavior for MFM-133­(Zr). The pressure dependence of the unit cell volume has been analyzed using a second-order Birch–Murnaghan equation of state (see ) to give a value for the bulk modulus B of 88.7 GPa (0–2 GPa), which is higher than for most other framework materials. However, this value is significantly lower than the bulk moduli for the Zr-based MOF materials UiO-67 (174 GPa) and UiO-abdc (580 GPa) over the same pressure range 0–2 GPa, reflecting the relative softness of MFM-133­(Zr).
elements.clean_text: High-pressure single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments were performed using a diamond anvil cell (DAC) (see ). Before loading a crystal into the DAC, residual DEF solvent from the synthesis was fully exchanged with 4:1 MeOH/EtOH, which was used as the pressure-transmitting medium. For MFM-133(Zr), diffraction data were collected at 293 K on one single crystal at pressures ranging from ambient  to 4.41 GPa. The variation of lattice parameter values as a function of pressure is shown in . It is immediately apparent that upon compression the equivalent a and b axes contract in length, but the c axis expands. Over the pressure range studied, lattice parameter a and the unit cell volume decrease by 0.628(5) Å (3.2%) and 521(6) Å3 (4.2%), respectively, while lattice parameter c increases by 0.732(8) Å (2.2%). The data were fitted using an empirical equation l = l 0 + λ(p - p c) v , giving the linear compressibilities along a (or b) and c as 5.9 and -5.1 TPa-1, respectively, over the pressure range 0-4.4 GPa. The value of NLC of -5.1 TPa-1 is higher than for other molecular frameworks such as [NH4][Zn(HCOO)3] (K NLC = -1.8 TPa-1) and ZAG-4 (K NLC = -2.6 TPa-1) but lower than metallocyanide frameworks Ag3[Co(CN)6]-I (K NLC = -76 TPa-1) and KMn[Ag(CN)2]3 (K NLC = -12 TPa-1), indicating moderately strong NLC behavior for MFM-133(Zr). The pressure dependence of the unit cell volume has been analyzed using a second-order Birch-Murnaghan equation of state (see ) to give a value for the bulk modulus B of 88.7 GPa (0-2 GPa), which is higher than for most other framework materials. However, this value is significantly lower than the bulk moduli for the Zr-based MOF materials UiO-67 (174 GPa) and UiO-abdc (580 GPa) over the same pressure range 0-2 GPa, reflecting the relative softness of MFM-133(Zr).

elements.content: High-pressure single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments for MFM-133­(Zr) reveal unusual NLC: (a) evolution of unit cell lattice parameters as a function of pressure with empirical fitting applied to the experimental data; (b) compressibilities as a function of pressure; (c) variation of unit cell volume with pressure, with the data fitted using a second-order Birch–Murnaghan equation of state; (d) compressibility indicatrix for MFM-133­(Zr) with positive linear compressibility shown in red (positive) and NLC in blue (negative). All axes are in units of TPa–1.
elements.clean_text: 2  High-pressure single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments for MFM-133(Zr) reveal unusual NLC: (a)  evolution of unit cell lattice parameters as a function of pressure with empirical fitting applied to the experimental data; (b) compressibilities as a function of pressure; (c) variation of unit cell volume with pressure, with the data fitted using a second-order Birch-Murnaghan equation of state; (d)  compressibility indicatrix for MFM-133(Zr) with positive linear compressibility shown in red (positive) and NLC in blue (negative). All axes are in units of TPa-1.

elements.content: The reversibility of the NLC shown by MFM-133­(Zr) was also assessed by collecting diffraction data upon sequential release of pressure to 2.76, 2.09, and 1.03 GPa. Indeed, the decompression results reveal that the NLC is fully reversible, with the lattice parameter a increasing from 19.016(3) Å at 4.41 GPa to 19.642(6) Å at 1.03 GPa and c decreasing from 33.102(8) Å at 4.41 GPa to 32.94(10) Å at 1.03 GPa. The unit cell volume also increases during decompression [11970(4) Å3 at 4.41 GPa to 12708(38) Å3 at 1.03 GPa]. This further confirms the flexibility and stability of this framework material, which is an important requirement for a material to find practical applications in high-pressure environments.
elements.clean_text: The reversibility of the NLC shown by MFM-133(Zr) was also assessed by collecting diffraction data upon sequential release of pressure to 2.76, 2.09, and 1.03 GPa. Indeed, the decompression results reveal that the NLC is fully reversible, with the lattice parameter a increasing from 19.016(3) Å at 4.41 GPa to 19.642(6) Å at 1.03 GPa and c decreasing from 33.102(8) Å at 4.41 GPa to 32.94(10) Å at 1.03 GPa. The unit cell volume also increases during decompression [11970(4) Å3 at 4.41 GPa to 12708(38) Å3 at 1.03 GPa]. This further confirms the flexibility and stability of this framework material, which is an important requirement for a material to find practical applications in high-pressure environments.

elements.content: In order to understand the mechanism underlying the NLC in MFM-133­(Zr) at a molecular level, we undertook an analysis of the structural changes under compression by constructing an octahedron with its vertices at the centroids of six {Zr6(μ3-OH)8(OH)8(COO)8} clusters. The octahedron can also be visualized as two identical rhombi sharing two axial vertices in a perpendicular fashion (a). Thus, two angles θ and δ can be used to define the shape of these rhombi (b). When the pressure is increased, θ decreases from 80.4° at 0.95 GPa to 78.1° at 4.28 GPa, a decrease of 2.9%, while δ increases by 2.4% over the same pressure range, from 49.8° to 51.0°. The ratio of the two diagonal axes of the rhombus (L 1/L 2, b) also increases from 1.18 at 0.95 GPa to 1.23 at 4.28 GPa. Examination of the relevant bond distances and angles indicates that the geometry of the {Zr6} inorganic cluster is unaffected by pressure. The decrease in θ and increase in δ and the ratios of diagonal axes of the rhombi under compression is reminiscent of the mechanism of the “wine-rack” motif, where the organic linkers act as rigid struts, while the inorganic clusters act as framework hinges. However, the framework of MFM-133­(Zr) is different from the two-dimensional wine-rack topology shown by molecular networks such as MIL-53, where contraction only affects one dimension of the crystal lattice. MFM-133­(Zr) contracts in two dimensions, resulting in the octahedral cage being distorted into a more elongated polyhedron (with increased ratio of the diagonal axes of 1.23 at 4.28 GPa compared to 1.18 at 0.95 GPa) under static compression.

The octahedron can also be visualized as two identical rhombi sharing two axial vertices in a perpendicular fashion (a). Thus, two angles θ and δ can be used to define the shape of these rhombi (b). When the pressure is increased, θ decreases from 80.4° at 0.95 GPa to 78.1° at 4.28 GPa, a decrease of 2.9%, while δ increases by 2.4% over the same pressure range, from 49.8° to 51.0°. The ratio of the two diagonal axes of the rhombus (L 1/L 2, b) also increases from 1.18 at 0.95 GPa to 1.23 at 4.28 GPa. Examination of the relevant bond distances and angles indicates that the geometry of the {Zr6} inorganic cluster is unaffected by pressure. The decrease in θ and increase in δ and the ratios of diagonal axes of the rhombi under compression is reminiscent of the mechanism of the "wine-rack" motif, where the organic linkers act as rigid struts, while the inorganic clusters act as framework hinges. However, the framework of MFM-133(Zr) is different from the two-dimensional wine-rack topology shown by molecular networks such as MIL-53, where contraction only affects one dimension of the crystal lattice. MFM-133(Zr) contracts in two dimensions, resulting in the octahedral cage being distorted into a more elongated polyhedron (with increased ratio of the diagonal axes of 1.23 at 4.28 GPa compared to 1.18 at 0.95 GPa) under static compression.

elements.content: Compressibility in MFM-133­(Zr). (a) Octahedral cage in MFM-133­(Zr) constructed by two identical rhombi (drawn in gold and green) sharing two axial vertices in a perpendicular fashion. (b) Simplified representation of the crystal structure of MFM-133­(Zr) viewed as the tessellation of the rhombi shown in (a) in two dimensions: {Zr6} clusters are represented as red circles and the organic linkers as dotted lines. Schematic diagram shows the effect of compression on the unit cell dimensions a and c as well as the angles θ and δ. Two diagonal axes of the octahedron are defined as L 1 and L 2. (c) Schematic representation of the change of shape of the octahedral cage under compression.
elements.clean_text: 3  Compressibility in MFM-133(Zr). (a) Octahedral cage in MFM-133(Zr) constructed by two identical rhombi (drawn in gold and green) sharing two axial vertices in a perpendicular fashion. (b) Simplified representation of the crystal structure of MFM-133(Zr) viewed as the tessellation of the rhombi shown in (a) in two dimensions: {Zr6} clusters are represented as red circles and the organic linkers as dotted lines. Schematic diagram shows the effect of compression on the unit cell dimensions a and c as well as the angles θ and δ. Two diagonal axes of the octahedron are defined as L 1 and L 2. (c) Schematic representation of the change of shape of the octahedral cage under compression.

elements.content: A close examination of the conformation of the organic linker within the whole pressure range shows that the dihedral angle between the two central mesitylene rings in MFM-133­(Zr) lies in the range 79–89° but does not follow a significant trend with increasing pressure. The limited variation of this dihedral angle indicates that there is restricted freedom of rotation between the central mesitylene rings. However, the relatively large octahedral cage is comprised of eight TCHB4– units. Therefore, the effect of the limited flexibility shown by one linker can by amplified, resulting in more noticeable flexibility observed for the overall structure.
elements.clean_text: A close examination of the conformation of the organic linker within the whole pressure range shows that the dihedral angle between the two central mesitylene rings in MFM-133(Zr) lies in the range 79-89° but does not follow a significant trend with increasing pressure. The limited variation of this dihedral angle indicates that there is restricted freedom of rotation between the central mesitylene rings. However, the relatively large octahedral cage is comprised of eight TCHB4- units. Therefore, the effect of the limited flexibility shown by one linker can by amplified, resulting in more noticeable flexibility observed for the overall structure.

elements.content: The response of single crystals of MFM-133­(Hf) to static pressures of up to 4.9 GPa at 293 K was analyzed using the same experimental methods as were applied for MFM-133­(Zr). MFM-133­(Hf) reveals the same NLC behavior as the Zr­(IV) analogue, with contraction along the a and b axes, expansion along the c axis, and a continuous decrease in unit cell volume with increasing pressure (). The lattice parameters at different pressures were fitted using the same empirical equation l = l 0 + λ­(p – p c) v as for MFM-133­(Zr) (see ). The lattice parameters a (or b) and c in MFM-133­(Hf) show a gradual respective decrease and increase with increasing pressure up to 4.9 GPa. This change in lattice parameters is different from that in MFM-133­(Zr), where the changes in a (or b) and c reach a plateau in the high-pressure region 3.5–4.5 GPa, indicating that the framework of MFM-133­(Zr) becomes significantly harder and cannot be further deformed with increasing pressure. Up to 3 GPa, the lattice parameters for both frameworks show similar decreases; however, above 3 GPa MFM-133­(Hf) reveals slightly larger changes in lattice parameters, e.g., by 4 GPa, the shrinkage in a is 4.3% [cf. 3.2% for MFM-133­(Zr)], and the expansion in c is 3.8% [cf. 2.4% for MFM-133­(Zr)]. Empirical fitting of the pressure-dependent lattice parameters gives compressibility values of 10.7 TPa–1 for a (or b) and −7.9 TPa–1 for c over the pressure range of 0–4.9 GPa, indicating that MFM-133­(Hf) shows a higher degree of NLC than the Zr­(IV) analogue. Significantly, by 4.9 GPa, the a (or b) axis in MFM-133­(Hf) has contracted by 6.5% compared to its starting value at ambient pressure, while the c axis has increased by 5.5%. The bulk modulus of MFM-133­(Hf) was estimated using a second-order Birch–Murnaghan equation of state () to give a value for B 0 of 44.8 GPa, lower than that of MFM-133­(Zr).

The lattice parameters a (or b) and c in MFM-133(Hf) show a gradual respective decrease and increase with increasing pressure up to 4.9 GPa. This change in lattice parameters is different from that in MFM-133(Zr), where the changes in a (or b) and c reach a plateau in the high-pressure region 3.5-4.5 GPa, indicating that the framework of MFM-133(Zr) becomes significantly harder and cannot be further deformed with increasing pressure. Up to 3 GPa, the lattice parameters for both frameworks show similar decreases; however, above 3 GPa MFM-133(Hf) reveals slightly larger changes in lattice parameters, e.g., by 4 GPa, the shrinkage in a is 4.3% [cf. 3.2% for MFM-133(Zr)], and the expansion in c is 3.8% [cf. 2.4% for MFM-133(Zr)]. Significantly, by 4.9 GPa, the a (or b) axis in MFM-133(Hf) has contracted by 6.5% compared to its starting value at ambient pressure, while the c axis has increased by 5.5%. elements.content: NLC in MFM-133­(Hf) revealed by high-pressure single-crystal X-ray diffraction: (a) evolution of unit cell lattice parameters for MFM-133­(Hf) as a function of pressure with empirical fits applied to the experimental data; (b) lattice compressibilities as a function of pressure; (c) variation of unit cell volume with pressure with the data fitted using a second-order Birch–Murnaghan equation of state; (d) compressibility indicatrix for MFM-133­(Hf) with the blue portion representing NLC effect. All axes are in units of TPa–1.
elements.clean_text: 4  NLC in MFM-133(Hf) revealed by high-pressure single-crystal X-ray diffraction: (a)  evolution of unit cell lattice parameters for MFM-133(Hf) as a function of pressure with empirical fits applied to the experimental data; (b) lattice compressibilities as a function of pressure; (c) variation of unit cell volume with pressure with the data fitted using a second-order Birch-Murnaghan equation of state; (d)  compressibility indicatrix for MFM-133(Hf) with the blue portion representing NLC effect. All axes are in units of TPa-1.

elements.content: The NLC in MFM-133­(Hf) involves the same mechanism as in its Zr­(IV) analogue, which is unsurprising given the isostructural nature of these two frameworks. Compared with the {Zr6} cluster, the {Hf6(μ3-OH)8(OH)8(COO)8} unit is slightly smaller due to the shorter Hf–O (COO) bond lengths within the studied pressure range (Hf1–O_A = 2.11–2.19 Å; Zr1–O_A = 2.22–2.28 Å; Hf2–O_B = 2.10–2.16 Å; Zr2–O_B = 2.15–2.21 Å, ) and is also unaffected by compression. Therefore, the flexibility of the octahedral cage comprising six {Hf6} clusters and eight TCHB4– units is largely attributable to the flexibility of the organic linkers which correspondingly arises from the twisted geometry of the two connected mesitylene rings in the TCHB4– units. The dihedral angle between these two central mesitylene rings in MFM-133­(Hf) lies in the range 70–80° above 1.5 GPa, which is about 10° less than that in MFM-133­(Zr), indicating the two central mesitylene rings in the TCHB4– in MFM-133­(Hf) are less twisted than in the Zr­(IV) structure in the higher pressure region (1.5–4 GPa). At the highest pressure studied for MFM-133­(Hf) (4.9 GPa), this angle reaches 71.2°, resulting in a very short C···C distance of 2.79 Å between the adjacent methyl groups on the two central mesitylene rings. The less twisted geometry of the mesitylene rings in MFM-133­(Hf) makes the linker unit lie flatter, bringing the equatorial {Hf6} clusters in the octahedral cage closer and pushing the two axial {Hf6} clusters further apart, thus resulting overall in a larger NLC effect ().
elements.clean_text: The NLC in MFM-133(Hf) involves the same mechanism as in its Zr(IV) analogue, which is unsurprising given the isostructural nature of these two frameworks. Compared with the {Zr6} cluster, the {Hf6(μ3-OH)8(OH)8(COO)8} unit is slightly smaller due to the shorter Hf-O (COO) bond lengths within the studied pressure range (Hf1-O_A = 2.11-2.19 Å; Zr1-O_A = 2.22-2.28 Å; Hf2-O_B = 2.10-2.16 Å; Zr2-O_B = 2.15-2.21 Å, ) and is also unaffected by compression. Therefore, the flexibility of the octahedral cage comprising six {Hf6} clusters and eight TCHB4- units is largely attributable to the flexibility of the organic linkers which correspondingly arises from the twisted geometry of the two connected mesitylene rings in the TCHB4- units. The dihedral angle between these two central mesitylene rings in MFM-133(Hf) lies in the range 70-80° above 1.5 GPa, which is about 10° less than that in MFM-133(Zr), indicating the two central mesitylene rings in the TCHB4- in MFM-133(Hf) are less twisted than in the Zr(IV) structure in the higher pressure region (1.5-4 GPa). At the highest pressure studied for MFM-133(Hf) (4.9 GPa), this angle reaches 71.2°, resulting in a very short C⋅⋅⋅C distance of 2.79 Å between the adjacent methyl groups on the two central mesitylene rings. The less twisted geometry of the mesitylene rings in MFM-133(Hf) makes the linker unit lie flatter, bringing the equatorial {Hf6} clusters in the octahedral cage closer and pushing the two axial {Hf6} clusters further apart, thus resulting overall in a larger NLC effect ().

elements.content: In summary, two isomorphous framework materials MFM-133­(M) (M = Hf, Zr) have been synthesized by employing a tetracarboxylic acid containing two central mesitylene rings and a twisted geometry within the linker. The inorganic component of the framework consists of octahedral {M6(μ3-OH)8(OH)8(COO)8} (M = Zr, Hf) clusters. The TCHB4– unit exhibits a tetrahedral arrangement of its four carboxylate groups, resulting in a rare flu topology for these frameworks. Both frameworks reveal unusual negative linear compressibility, where under static pressure contraction of the a and b axes is accompanied by expansion of the c axis. This is the first observation of NLC behavior in molecular frameworks of flu topology, and these two materials are among limited examples of porous molecular structures showing NLC. The NLC in MFM-133­(M) (M = Zr, Hf) follows a wine-rack mechanism where the octahedral cage (with six {M6} clusters as the vertices and eight TCHB4– units as the faces) contracts equatorially and expand axially. MFM-133­(Hf) reveals larger linear compressibilities in all three directions than MFM-133­(Zr) over the pressure range studied (0–4.9 GPa). Thus, we demonstrate that the NLC in materials can be effectively tuned by simply varying the inorganic component of the framework without changing the structure of materials. It is anticipated that the high-pressure studies on MFM-133­(M) (M = Zr, Hf) and the resulting knowledge of the mechanism by which NLC occurs will lead to the exploitation of such NLC materials in various applications such as pressure-sensitive sensors.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, two isomorphous framework materials MFM-133(M) (M = Hf, Zr) have been synthesized by employing a tetracarboxylic acid containing two central mesitylene rings and a twisted geometry within the linker. The inorganic component of the framework consists of octahedral {M6(μ3-OH)8(OH)8(COO)8} (M = Zr, Hf) clusters. The TCHB4- unit exhibits a tetrahedral arrangement of its four carboxylate groups, resulting in a rare flu topology for these frameworks. Both frameworks reveal unusual negative linear compressibility, where under static pressure contraction of the a and b axes is accompanied by expansion of the c axis. This is the first observation of NLC behavior in molecular frameworks of flu topology, and these two materials are among limited examples of porous molecular structures showing NLC. The NLC in MFM-133(M) (M = Zr, Hf) follows a wine-rack mechanism where the octahedral cage (with six {M6} clusters as the vertices and eight TCHB4- units as the faces) contracts equatorially and expand axially. MFM-133(Hf) reveals larger linear compressibilities in all three directions than MFM-133(Zr) over the pressure range studied (0-4.9 GPa). Thus, we demonstrate that the NLC in materials can be effectively tuned by simply varying the inorganic component of the framework without changing the structure of materials. It is anticipated that the high-pressure studies on MFM-133(M) (M = Zr, Hf) and the resulting knowledge of the mechanism by which NLC occurs will lead to the exploitation of such NLC materials in various applications such as pressure-sensitive sensors.

elements.content: The ligand H4TCHB was synthesized using the reported procedure. A mixture of H4TCHB (0.05 g, 0.07 mmol), ZrCl4 (0.049 g, 0.21 mmol), and benzoic acid (1.75 g, 14.3 mmol) was dissolved in DEF (10 mL) using a sonication bath. The resulting solution was heated at 120 °C for 48 h, after which colorless polyhedral crystals were collected by filtration and washed with fresh DEF (3 × 20 mL). Yield: 0.104 g (70%). Anal. Calcd for C95H152N10O26Zr3: C, 53.98; H, 7.17; N, 6.56%. Found: C, 53.80; H, 7.01; N, 6.25%.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of [Zr3(μ3-OH)4(OH)4(C46H34O8)]⋅10DEF, MFM-133(Zr)

The ligand H4TCHB was synthesized using the reported procedure. A mixture of H4TCHB (0.05 g, 0.07 mmol), ZrCl4 (0.049 g, 0.21 mmol), and benzoic acid (1.75 g, 14.3 mmol) was dissolved in DEF (10 mL) using a sonication bath. The resulting solution was heated at 120 °C for 48 h, after which colorless polyhedral crystals were collected by filtration and washed with fresh DEF (3 × 20 mL). Yield: 0.104 g (70%). Anal. Calcd for C95H152N10O26Zr3: C, 53.98; H, 7.17; N, 6.56%. Found: C, 53.80; H, 7.01; N, 6.25%.

elements.content: A mixture of H4TCHB (0.05 g, 0.07 mmol), HfCl4 (0.067 g, 0.21 mmol), and benzoic acid (1.75 g, 14.3 mmol) was dissolved in DEF (10 mL) using a sonication bath. The resulting solution was heated at 120 °C for 48 h, after which colorless polyhedral crystals were collected by filtration and washed with fresh DMF (3 × 20 mL). Yield: 0.12 g (75%). Anal. Calcd for C91H141N9O25Hf3: C, 47.59; H, 6.19; N, 5.49%. Found: C, 47.22; H, 6.14; N, 5.13%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Hf3(μ3-OH)4(OH)4(C46H34O8)]⋅9DEF, MFM-133(Hf)

A mixture of H4TCHB (0.05 g, 0.07 mmol), HfCl4 (0.067 g, 0.21 mmol), and benzoic acid (1.75 g, 14.3 mmol) was dissolved in DEF (10 mL) using a sonication bath. The resulting solution was heated at 120 °C for 48 h, after which colorless polyhedral crystals were collected by filtration and washed with fresh DMF (3 × 20 mL). Yield: 0.12 g (75%). Anal. Calcd for C91H141N9O25Hf3: C, 47.59; H, 6.19; N, 5.49%. Found: C, 47.22; H, 6.14; N, 5.13%.

elements.content: High-pressure experiments were carried out using a locally assembled Merrill-Basset diamond anvil cell (DAC) [opening angle 37°, Boehler-Almax anvil type 1A, WC backing plates and 200 μm tungsten gaskets]. A colorless crystal of MFM-133­(Zr) or MFM-133­(Hf) was loaded into the DAC with a ruby sphere as the pressure calibrant and 4:1 methanol/ethanol as the pressure-transmitting medium (PTM). Diffraction data were recorded using either Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å with microfocus source and focusing mirrors) on an in-house Rigaku Oxford Diffraction SuperNova diffractometer equipped with an Eos CCD detector or monochromatic synchrotron radiation (λ = 0.6889 Å) on a Rigaku Saturn 724+ CCD diffractometer on Beamline I19 at Diamond Light Source. Diffraction data were processed using the program CrysAlisPRO (Version 1.171.37.31). Structures were solved by transferring the fractional coordinates of the atoms as determined at an adjacent pressure and refined using SHELXL-2014. Satisfactory structural refinements were obtained from all data sets. Due to the inherent low completeness of the diffraction data caused by the presence of the diamond anvil cell, restraints were required. Crystal data are summarized in Tables S1–S3 and S7. The X-ray crystallographic structure files can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.
elements.clean_text:
High-Pressure Crystallography

High-pressure experiments were carried out using a locally assembled Merrill-Basset diamond anvil cell (DAC) [opening angle 37°, Boehler-Almax anvil type 1A, WC backing plates and 200 μm tungsten gaskets]. A colorless crystal of MFM-133(Zr) or MFM-133(Hf) was loaded into the DAC with a ruby sphere as the pressure calibrant and 4:1 methanol/ethanol as the pressure-transmitting medium (PTM). Diffraction data were recorded using either Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å with microfocus source and focusing mirrors) on an in-house Rigaku Oxford Diffraction SuperNova diffractometer equipped with an Eos CCD detector or monochromatic synchrotron radiation (λ = 0.6889 Å) on a Rigaku Saturn 724+ CCD diffractometer on Beamline I19 at Diamond Light Source. Diffraction data were processed using the program CrysAlisPRO (Version 1.171.37.31). Structures were solved by transferring the fractional coordinates of the atoms as determined at an adjacent pressure and refined using SHELXL-2014. Satisfactory structural refinements were obtained from all data sets. Due to the inherent low completeness of the diffraction data caused by the presence of the diamond anvil cell, restraints were required. Crystal data are summarized in Tables S1-S3 and S7. The X-ray crystallographic structure files can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

cln_elements.content: Single-crystal structure of MFM-133­(Zr) at ambient pressure and 120 K. Views of (a) the octahedral {Zr6(μ3-OH)8(OH)8(COO)8} cluster and H4TCHB; (b) the conformation of TCHB4– units in the framework showing the twisted geometry of the two central mesitylene rings; (c) the octahedral cage constructed from eight TCHB4– units and six {Zr6} clusters; (d) the (4,8)-connected flu-type topology of MFM-133­(Zr). Color scheme: Zr, green; O, red; C, black.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Single-crystal structure of MFM-133(Zr) at ambient pressure and 120 K. Views of (a) the octahedral {Zr6(μ3-OH)8(OH)8(COO)8} cluster and H4TCHB; (b) the conformation of TCHB4- units in the framework showing the twisted geometry of the two central mesitylene rings; (c) the octahedral cage constructed from eight TCHB4- units and six {Zr6} clusters; (d) the (4,8)-connected flu-type topology of MFM-133(Zr). Color scheme: Zr, green; O, red; C, black.

cln_elements.content: High-pressure single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments for MFM-133­(Zr) reveal unusual NLC: (a) evolution of unit cell lattice parameters as a function of pressure with empirical fitting applied to the experimental data; (b) compressibilities as a function of pressure; (c) variation of unit cell volume with pressure, with the data fitted using a second-order Birch–Murnaghan equation of state; (d) compressibility indicatrix for MFM-133­(Zr) with positive linear compressibility shown in red (positive) and NLC in blue (negative). All axes are in units of TPa–1.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  High-pressure single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments for MFM-133(Zr) reveal unusual NLC: (a)  evolution of unit cell lattice parameters as a function of pressure with empirical fitting applied to the experimental data; (b) compressibilities as a function of pressure; (c) variation of unit cell volume with pressure, with the data fitted using a second-order Birch-Murnaghan equation of state; (d)  compressibility indicatrix for MFM-133(Zr) with positive linear compressibility shown in red (positive) and NLC in blue (negative). All axes are in units of TPa-1.

cln_elements.content: Compressibility in MFM-133­(Zr). (a) Octahedral cage in MFM-133­(Zr) constructed by two identical rhombi (drawn in gold and green) sharing two axial vertices in a perpendicular fashion. (b) Simplified representation of the crystal structure of MFM-133­(Zr) viewed as the tessellation of the rhombi shown in (a) in two dimensions: {Zr6} clusters are represented as red circles and the organic linkers as dotted lines. Schematic diagram shows the effect of compression on the unit cell dimensions a and c as well as the angles θ and δ. Two diagonal axes of the octahedron are defined as L 1 and L 2. (c) Schematic representation of the change of shape of the octahedral cage under compression.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Compressibility in MFM-133(Zr). (a) Octahedral cage in MFM-133(Zr) constructed by two identical rhombi (drawn in gold and green) sharing two axial vertices in a perpendicular fashion. (b) Simplified representation of the crystal structure of MFM-133(Zr) viewed as the tessellation of the rhombi shown in (a) in two dimensions: {Zr6} clusters are represented as red circles and the organic linkers as dotted lines. Schematic diagram shows the effect of compression on the unit cell dimensions a and c as well as the angles θ and δ. Two diagonal axes of the octahedron are defined as L 1 and L 2. (c) Schematic representation of the change of shape of the octahedral cage under compression.

cln_elements.content: NLC in MFM-133­(Hf) revealed by high-pressure single-crystal X-ray diffraction: (a) evolution of unit cell lattice parameters for MFM-133­(Hf) as a function of pressure with empirical fits applied to the experimental data; (b) lattice compressibilities as a function of pressure; (c) variation of unit cell volume with pressure with the data fitted using a second-order Birch–Murnaghan equation of state; (d) compressibility indicatrix for MFM-133­(Hf) with the blue portion representing NLC effect. All axes are in units of TPa–1.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  NLC in MFM-133(Hf) revealed by high-pressure single-crystal X-ray diffraction: (a)  evolution of unit cell lattice parameters for MFM-133(Hf) as a function of pressure with empirical fits applied to the experimental data; (b) lattice compressibilities as a function of pressure; (c) variation of unit cell volume with pressure with the data fitted using a second-order Birch-Murnaghan equation of state; (d)  compressibility indicatrix for MFM-133(Hf) with the blue portion representing NLC effect. All axes are in units of TPa-1.

metadata.title:
Unusual
and Tunable Negative Linear Compressibility
in the Metal–Organic Framework MFM-133(M) (M = Zr, Hf)
